prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Since we are aiming for a line-integrated detection over 400 km/s the coarsest spectral resolution (i.e. the continuum mode resolution) is sufficient as it provides a resolution of approx. 15 km/s.

We require the coarsest angular resolution available in band 9 to ensure maximal detection sensitivity. This implies configuration C36-1. Note that our sources rise above 30deg elevation for at least 8 hours during the night time in March 2016 such that these can be scheduled despite being high-frequency scans.

We have used the `Compendium of far-IR line and continuum emission' by Brauher et al. (2008) and literature measurements of molecular gas in ellipticals (e.g. Sofue \& Wakamatsu 1993, Welch et al. 2010, Oca{\~n}a Flaquer et al. 2010, Young et al. 2011) to derive the range of light-to-mass ratios $L_{\rm [CII]}/M({\rm H_2})$ found for local elliptical galaxies that were observed with the Long Wavelength Spectrometer (LWS) on {\it ISO}. The corresponding distribution function (upper/lower limits on the ratio are accounted for by the appropriate statistical method of survival analysis) shown in Fig. 2 allows us to estimate the expected strength of the [CII] line in our target. The distribution about the median ratio (vertical red line) of 0.12\,$L_{\odot}/M_{\odot}$ is broad and subject to considerable scatter which also encompasses the typical $L_{\rm [CII]}$-to-total (atomic \& molecular) gas ratio of $\sim$0.03\,$L_{\odot}/M_{\odot}$ found in star-forming systems at low- and high-$z$. Note that although some of these local ellipticals are LINERs, their (usually weak) AGN is {\it not} the likely cause for this offset as the LINERs in the local sample span the entire range of observed $L_{\rm [CII]}/M({\rm H_2})$ ratios. Conversely, {\bf the sample average $\langle L_{\rm [CII]}/M({\rm H_2})\rangle$\,=\,0.12\,$L_{\odot}/M_{\odot}$ is observed in very different galaxies of elliptical morphology (e.g. the dwarf elliptical NGC 185 and the massive, 10$^{11}$\,$M_{\odot}$ elliptical NGC 4278), so we hold it to be a representative basis} for the subsequent sensitivity requirement.
Our goal is to achieve a significant detection of the [CII] line in very massive $z$\,=\,1.8 passive galaxies. At $z\,\sim$\,1.8 the [CII] line at 157.714\,${\mu}$m is redshifted into ALMA band 9 at $\sim$674\,GHz. The field of view of the observations is 9$''$ and hence comfortably covers our target which will be unresolved (c.f. Fig. 3, left) in the compact configuration C32-1 which is suited to this detection experiment. Given the stellar masses of (2-4)\,$\times$\,$10^{11}$\,$M_{\odot}$ of our targets and for a gas fraction of $f_{\rm gas}$\,$\simeq$\,1\% we predict a line luminosity $L_{\rm [CII]}$\,=\,(3-6)$\times$10$^8$\,$L_{\odot}$ if (as motivated above) $L_{\rm [CII]}/M({\rm H_2})$\,$\simeq$\,0.12\,$L_{\odot}/M_{\odot}$. This translates to a line flux of $I_{\rm [CII]}$\,=\,(1.6-3.6)\,Jy\,km/s if we assume a line width of 400\,km/s -- consistent with the limit on the stellar dispersion $\sigma_{\star}$\,$<$\,326\,km/s derived by Onodera et al. (2010). The wide 7.5\,GHz bandwidth of ALMA (much larger than the expected line width $\sim$0.9\,GHz) will permit the detection/subtraction of continuum emission if present. We request 30 min. of on-source integration for the three of our most massive targets, ensuring a detection of a 0.5\% gas fraction with $S/N$\,$>$\,3. Using the ALMA OT we found that multiples of 30 min. provide the most favourable balance between on-source time and overheads (which amount to 60\% here). For our 4$^{\rm th}$ somewhat less massive elliptical (included in order to probe the ISM in a truly compact ($r/\langle r_{z=0}\rangle$\,$\simeq$\,0.2) we request 1 hr of observing time (1.7 hr incl. overheads) implying a {\bf total time request of 4.2 hours (2.5 hours on-source) of ALMA cycle 1 time}. The targeted sensitivities range from 0.75 to 1\,mJy (employing dual polarization), depending on the target. Note that even if $L_{\rm [CII]}/M({\rm H_2})$\,=\,0.03\,$L_{\odot}/M_{\odot}$, as commonly found in low- and high-$z$ star-forming galaxies, these observations will be sufficient to detect gas fractions down to 2\% reliably (5\,$\sigma$). In the case of even lower gas fractions the {\bf stacked line emission of our targets will allow us to measure a population average of f$_{\rm gas}$\,=\,1\% (typical of local ellipticals) even under pessimistic assumptions about the $L_{\rm [CII]}/M({\rm H_2})$ light-to-mass ratio.}

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The gas content of early-type galaxies is all but unknown beyond the nearby Universe, despite being a key element for the understanding galaxy quenching. We propose to observe the [CII] in four massive (Mstar>2e+11) z~1.8 elliptical galaxies in the COSMOS field in order to constrain their gas fraction. Observing the [CII] emission line has the major advantage that at fixed integration time - ALMA can detect gas fractions that are 25 times smaller than those which can be obtained through, e.g, CO follow-up with current sub-mm observatories. Given the large mass of our target ellipticals, we expect to detect the [CII] line even if their gas fraction is as low as 1% and hence similar to that found in local CO-detected early type galaxies. If successful, the proposed observations would represent the first detection of cold gas in high-z early-type galaxies, allowing its ISM properties to be compared to both low- and high-z star-forming galaxies and state-of-the art numerical simulations, thereby opening up a new field of high-redshift studies. With current ALMA capabilities, our detection experiment requires 5.2 hours of integration time in band 9 and the compact configuration.
